(Sorry I haven�t posted. I am officially sick, so if this makes somewhere 
next to no sense then I wanna apologize now. Half the e-mails I read were 
blurry^_^)

Tavatron had often wondered what may have been if certain circumstances had 
not effected her life so greatly. Perhaps she would be back on Beta Prime, 
arguing with her parents over trivial issues. At the time they were matters 
of great importance, now, however, they seemed like nothing compared to 
current problems. So much had changed in such a small amount of time. It had 
only taken hours before the colony was in ruins:

"They did not know what hit them."

Tavatron continued walking steadily onward, toward the CF. The lazy breezes 
blew past her, carrying new scents and sounds with them. This planet, the 
surrounding area, reminded her of an old song from earth. It was something 
about life, something her mother used to sing. She could vaguely recall the 
tune and a few words, but nothing else. It had been ages since she even 
thought about it, much less tried to recall what her mother looked like. The 
past could be quite painful, especially when one has run from it for so 
long:

"Before I joined the forces I lived on Beta Prime; a colony in the Triceron 
Galaxy. We called it the Wasteland. It was a desert. The small community 
that was there consisted mainly of miners and soldiers. There were a few 
families, mine included."

Tavatron watched absentmindedly as two butterflies danced past her. They 
seemed to be dancing, almost floating on the unseen currents of the wind. 
They reminded her of the glade she and Dinobot had visited not too long ago. 
It had been beautiful, and the butterflies had been one of the first things 
she had laid eyes on. There were many of them, all dancing past her and 
beyond, into the surrounding forest. It had been so peaceful, so pleasant, 
and then the memory of the glade�s destruction flooded back, swamping her. 
Why was everything she ever cared for, even had the slightest feeling for, 
always taken from her at the last moment? Whenever she had begun to feel 
comfortable, and� safe, something would happen. On Beta Prime it had been 
the fire, on Earth, Obliteratron.

"There was a terrorist raid."

Tavatron sighed deeply. This was too much. It was taking all her will and 
inner strength to summon up that which she had worked so long and hard to 
suppress. She could see the scene before her once again, the buildings 
cracking and burning, their supports no longer able to sustain their giant 
frames.

"Most that didn�t die in the fires were slaughtered by the storms. The 
sandstorms were like a fire themselves. They tore at a �bot until there was 
nothing left."

She shuddered to think of the poor souls that did survive the storms. They 
hadn�t lasted long. Tavatron could still hear their terrified cries. Without 
proper medical treatment they hadn�t stood a chance:

"Out of the 285 colonists only 15 survived."

She had suppressed most of the time on Beta Prime, all but the few precious 
memories she had of herself and an old friend. Ironically he had been a male 
desert lizard of some sort and a native of the planet. She couldn�t remember 
his name anymore. Actually, now that she thought about it, she had never 
really learned it. She had called him Lizard, probably because she couldn�t 
pronounce his real name:

"I was 5 when the raid destroyed my home. My parents were killed in a storm 
soon after. One other transformer of the same age and myself left the planet 
two years later with the surviving colonists."

Tavatron didn�t know why she was telling him all of this. Perhaps she would 
feel better once she had shared it with someone. No one knew of the raid. 
The government had done a superb job of erasing all traces of the colonists, 
including the old identities of the survivors. The adults had been given new 
names and expensive jobs, while the few surviving children were left to 
wander aimlessly through the streets. According to a file she had 
�liberated� with the aid of a few other survivors they were expendable 
commodities:

"We were expendable."

Tavatron kicked up small dust clouds as she walked, quietly humming an old 
tune under her breath. It took her several more moments before she realized 
what she was doing. She had always hummed a certain song while kicking up 
sand in the desert. It was a game she and her friends used to play. The 
object was to see who could kick the sand the highest before the song ended. 
Tavatron quickly cleared her throat and looked away. She had avoiding any 
eye contact with Dinobot this entire time, and now she was afraid he had 
noticed her little slip. The song she had been humming was slow and steady, 
but with a bouncy beat to it. She was still stepping in time to it, however, 
though she hadn�t realized it yet:

"When I was old enough I joined the forces."

She had been a Predacon at the time, but it hadn�t taken much to convince 
her to switch sides. Death had been the final straw:

"Someone who was very close to me died while serving in the forces. He had 
been shot and burned nearly beyond recognition. When I saw him he was laying 
on a metal table in a make shift medical facility with tubes down his 
throat�"

A gentle cawing brought Tavatron out of her zombie like state. She had 
forgotten she was talking, and whom she was talking to. The past was past, 
why did he have to force her to bring it up again? Tavatron took a deep 
breath. She was almost done, and the base loomed on the distant horizon. She 
had been talking for some time, something she was prone to do when it came 
to matters of the past. The base, however, was still a long way off. It 
would take them a little longer to get there, but not much:

"He died."

She remembered how his parents had cried when she told them the horrible 
news. She had stood there, back straight and gaze unwavering, while they 
sobbed in each other�s arms. All the while all she could think was why him? 
She was too stunned, and too well trained to resort to tears. Sorrow was a 
weak emotion. After deserting and joining the Maximal forces she had 
regained some of her feelings, but not enough. She still couldn�t shed tears 
for her fallen comrades, and most likely never would.

"When I saw you lying there, you reminded me of something I had fought long 
and hard to forget. I couldn�t handle it."

Most �bots would have regretted spending their childhood stealing and 
running wild through the streets. She had no regrets. She had learned things 
on the streets that no school could ever teach her, things that had saved 
her life countless times over. She wanted to forget, but knew she couldn�t. 
Her past was a part of her, whether she liked it or not.

Tavatron knew this was no excuse for her actions, and Dinobot would probably 
agree with her. But right now all she wanted to do was rest, or at least eat 
something. Too much had happened in too little a time frame for her to go 
any longer without food or sleep. She wanted to tell Dinobot as well, but he 
was probably too sore to hunt. She had to fight the urge to pounce on even 
the smallest of creatures.

Tavatron looked toward her companion, as always he had a scowl on his face, 
as if he were deep in thought or about to kill something. Tavatron stared 
aimlessly into the cloudy sky, occasionally watching a bird or two glide 
past. Tavatron�s gaze drifted toward the CF, where she could barely make out 
the outlines of the Alliance gestalts.

"The Cybertronian Fire is under attack!"

Tavatron reverted to beast mode and turned to see if Dinobot had heard her. 
She didn�t have the time to wait right now, the CF was in trouble:

"We have to hurry, or else we may arrive too late."

Tavatron began to run across the plains as quickly as possible. Her paws 
pounded against the soft earth as she tore across it. If now was ever the 
time to utilize her enhancements, this was it.
